newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Release of Thai stocks seen hammering rubber price.
newsitem.headline: Release of Thai stocks seen hammering rubber price.

text.p: Southeast Asian rubber prices will take a further pounding if Thailand sells its excess stocks in the market, rubber dealers said on Tuesday.

The sale of the stocks, which a Thai industry official told an industry conference range between 120,000-150,000 tonnes, may force the International Natural Rubber Organisation (INRO) to intervene in the market if prices fall further.
"The market as a whole cannot but sink slowly," a paper by a Japanese rubber house said.

"Prices would easily hit the INRO 'must-buy' level," another trader said, refering to INRO's previous announcement that it would buy rubber in the market if prices fell to 172 Malaysian/ Singapore cents a kg.
Thailand, the world's biggest producer of natural rubber, has been trying to prop up prices by buying large amounts of rubber from its farmers.
Rubber prices have been suffering from weak demand for months.
